metadata.title: Metric on Nonlinear Dynamical Systems with Perron-Frobenius Operators
metadata.author: Isao Ishikawa, Keisuke Fujii, Masahiro Ikeda, Yuka Hashimoto, Yoshinobu Kawahara
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: The development of a metric for structural data is a long-term problem in pattern recognition and machine learning. In this paper, we develop a general metric for comparing nonlinear dynamical systems that is defined with Perron-Frobenius operators in reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces. Our metric includes the existing fundamental metrics for dynamical systems, which are basically defined with principal angles between some appropriately-chosen subspaces, as its special cases. We also describe the estimation of our metric from finite data. We empirically illustrate our metric with an example of rotation dynamics in a unit disk in a complex plane, and evaluate the performance with real-world time-series data.

highlights: Classification and recognition has been one of the main focuses of research in machine learning for the past decades
We develop a general metric for nonlinear dynamical systems, which includes the existing fundamental metrics for dynamical systems mentioned above as its special cases
We propose a general metric for the comparison of nonlinear dynamical systems, which is defined with Perron-Frobenius operators in reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces
We developed a general metric for comparing nonlinear dynamical systems that is defined with Koopman operator in reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces
We described that our metric includes Martin’s metric and Binet-Cauchy kernels for dynamical systems as its special cases
We empirically showed the effectiveness of our metric using an example of rotation dynamics in a unit disk in a complex plane and real-world time-series data

summary: Classification and recognition has been one of the main focuses of research in machine learning for the past decades.
We empirically illustrate our metric using an example of rotation dynamics in a unit disk in a complex plane, and evaluate the performance with real-world time-series data.
Let X = H be the RKHS associated with the positive definite kernel k|M⇥M defined by the restriction of k to M ⇥ M, which is a function space on M.

We derive an formula to compute the above metric from finite data, which allows us to compare several time-series data generated from dynamical systems just by evaluating the values of kernel funcWItinoenthsdi.seFfisienrcsetti,oawnl,eintahereagriuneoitptihaeleravctaoolmruefiAn:imtBeConka:,nMdHtihbney=nteiN,=ta1hned7!ffoorrmPvu1iNl=,a.1f.oa.ri,vcvioN.m2WpueHtankti,ooMtne..

We regard X = Rq. The positive definite kernel here is the usual inner product of Rq and the associated RKHS is canonically isomorphic to Cq. Let Hin = Cq and Hob = Cr. Note that for i = 1, 2, Di = (Ai, Ci, Iq) 2 T (Cq, Cr), and for any linear maps f : Rq !
We discuss the relation between our metric and the Binet-Cauchy kernels on dynamical systems defined by Vishwanathan et al [25, Section 5].

Instead of introducing such an exponential discounting, our idea to construct a mathematically valid kernel is considering the limit of the ratio of kernels defined via finite series of the orbits of dynamical systems.

We empirically illustrate how our metric works with synthetic data of the rotation dynamics on the unit disk in a complex plane in Subsection 5.1, and evaluate the discriminate performance of our metric with real-world time-series data in Subsection 5.2.
The last metric called Koopman spectral kernels [8] generalized the kernel defined by Vishwanathan et al [25] to the nonlinear dynamical systems and outperformed the method.

We developed a general metric for comparing nonlinear dynamical systems that is defined with Koopman operator in RKHSs. We described that our metric includes Martin’s metric and Binet-Cauchy kernels for dynamical systems as its special cases.
We empirically showed the effectiveness of our metric using an example of rotation dynamics in a unit disk in a complex plane and real-world time-series data.
headline: We develop a general metric for comparing nonlinear dynamical systems that is defined with Perron-Frobenius operators in reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces
